background: Depression and anxiety frequently co-occur, impacting treatment outcomes, and understanding the underlying mechanisms is crucial.
hypotheses: Can a common factor characterize the general structure of bridging symptoms in depression-anxiety comorbidity?
Are there neural markers supporting the neurobiological foundation of this common factor?
What connectome-based markers characterize this common factor?
What are the multiscale genetic substrates for these connectome-based markers?
major_findings: A common bridging factor (cb factor) was identified from 12 bridging symptoms, predicting comorbidity robustly.
This cb factor was predicted using edge-centric connectomes (eFCs), particularly in attention and frontoparietal networks.
These eFC patterns were moderately heritable and associated with genetic markers enriched in vasculature and cerebellar development, especially during late childhood to young adulthood.
Connectome-transcriptional markers were identified, revealing neurobiological enrichment in vasculature and cerebellar development, particularly during late childhood to young adulthood.
new_open_questions: How does the cb factor generalize to clinical populations and other assessment methods?
What are the precise mechanisms by which genetic variations influence the identified eFC patterns and their association with the cb factor?
Can these findings inform the development of targeted interventions for depression-anxiety comorbidity?
